definitions.definition: a large round container, usually made of wood or metal, with flat ends and, usually, curved sides

examples.text: They filled the barrels with cider.
The art of barrel-making is an ancient skill.

definitions.definition: the contents of or the amount contained in a barrel; a unit of measurement in the oil industry equal to between 120 and 159 litres

examples.text: They got through two barrels of beer.
Oil prices fell to $9 a barrel.
Crude oil prices hit record highs of more than $70 a barrel.

definitions.definition: the part of a gun like a tube through which the bullets are fired

examples.text: Tom found himself looking down the barrel of a gun.
The barrel was aimed directly at me.
He fired one barrel and then fired again.
I felt the gun barrel at my head.
Pulling his rifle to his shoulder he squinted along the barrel.
Life hasn't exactly been a barrel of laughs lately.

definitions.definition: used to emphasize how easy it is to do something

examples.text: What do you mean you can't do it? It'll be like shooting fish in a barrel!
He sold the business lock, stock and barrel.

definitions.definition: (to put/have somebody) in a situation in which they must accept or do what you want

examples.text: They've got us over a barrel. Either we agree to their terms or we lose the money.

definitions.definition: to have to use things or people that are not the best or most suitable because the ones that were the best or most suitable are no longer available

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French baril, from medieval Latin barriclus ‘small cask’.
